comments.text:
In the video they set a bad example in terms of the risks they are willing 
to take. I split lanes when cars are side-by-side, but when cars space out, 
they can always change lanes suddenly--I bet that is the #1 cause of 
serious freeway lane-splitting accidents. Avoid that situation by just 
being patient, and when you to to the front of the intersection and the 
light turns green, look both ways and wait a second--for idiots running red 
lights. People confuse safe lane-splitting with idiots doing dangerous 
things on motorcycles while lane-splitting--two different things. Most 
lane-splitters I see (I mean, greater than 50%) do stuff I wouldn't do. You 
wouldn't call a motorcyclist weaving through traffic a lane-splitter if 
they took the full lane on every pass of a car, but such riders are simply 
rolling the dice each time they pass a car--and one day they're going to be 
at the wrong place at the exact wrong time and get taken out--this is no 
different than people in cars who are speeding and weaving through 
traffic--it's dangerous because drivers are not expecting to be suddenly 
overtaken, and many people are not alert for rapidly approaching vehicles 
when they lane change. Safe lane-splitting is safe. Dangerous 
lane-splitting is dangerous. I see many lane-splitting motorcyclists who 
are clearly inexperienced and don't understand the difference.﻿

accidents here is due to variety of things including: lack of driving 
education, people breaking rules, and not wearing safety gear. Car and

what you need to worry about is completely different from the West. People 
are constantly running red lights, turning right when they aren't supposed 
to, going in the wrong direction on roads, not using headlights, etc. You 
also constantly have cars and trucks veering into scooter/motorcycle lanes 
due to their bad driving/blatant disregard for the rules. Finally, the idea 
of safety gear is virtually non-existent. In Taiwan, a helmet is required, 
but most wear cheap turtle hats instead of full face helmets and wearing 
anything else is usually scoffed at.

splitting, but if done safely it can also be the correct choice. If you're 
stuck behind a slow pack of vehicles and someone comes behind you in a 
hurry, there is no where else to go. We make it our job to understand and 
predict what cars are going to do. We learn how to read tires, lane 
positioning, and driving behavior to better understand what people are 
planning. I personally don't lane split at these speeds, but I do believe 
it is acceptable when done correctly. That absolutely does not mean 
speeding past everyone because you want to go 100+ or speeding past slow 
moving traffic, but going an acceptable, responsible speed.

be allowed. But another way to avoid getting rear ended without actually 
fully lane splitting is simply stopping in between the first pair of

continuing to travel all the way to the front. Or if its single lane road 
doing the same thing but stopping on the line marking the shoulder next to 
the stopped car. That way you are not directly in line with the car traffic 
approaching behind you making it much less likely that a car will rear end 
you but rather it would rear end the car next you. Lane splitting at 
anything above 20 miles an hour in any sort of moving traffic is just plain 
foolish. And stop and go traffic on a highway is even riskier since cars, 
even when they are only moving at 10 or 20 miles an hour are unpredictable 
since drivers have a habit of switching between lanes when the other lane 
next to them starts moving ahead. Watch the opening scenes of Office Space 
to see a funny take on just that scenario. Drivers are just in to much of a
